title: How much does book piracy impact author royalties? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s very difficult to say, because it depends so much on variable factors, and there is no way to calculate what the sales would have been in a world where piracy doesn’t exist. I had a book pirated, and from sales data I would have made twice as much on that book if it hadn’t been pirated. On the other hand, those who illegally downloaded it clearly weren’t willing to spend money, so maybe they wouldn’t have bought it at all if there hadn’t been a pirated version available. Other variables include the popularity of the author, whether they have a fanbase who would spend money because they admire the author, even if they weren’t enthusiastic for the book itself, the book’s price (an ebook sold at $0.99 will have a different impact to a paperback selling at 9.99), and a number of other things. Bottom line: Piracy is bad and hurts authors. Don’t do it.

Probably not at all. If you write Harry Potter, maybe. But most books sell so little that they don’t generate much interest at all from piracy. There is some current ideas that piracy actually helps spread interest in your book and increases sales. Your book is piracy worthy. It helps if you put references to your other books in back or somewhere of your current book. Spreading your book around gets people interested. Most people don’t steal books. So you can run on that most people will just go and buy a new copy if they are interested. I wouldn’t worry about it at all. I would cross reference your other books and just keep moving forward
